frameDefinitions: A Cognizer has a piece of Content in their model of the world.
A Cognizer construes an Item as belonging to a certain Category.
This frame concerns a Cognizer's certainty about the correctness of beliefs  or expectations.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer believing that some Phenomenon will take place in the future.
A Concept_1 is related to Concept_2 by some Evidence.

A Cognizer possesses knowledge about the workings, significance, or meaning of an idea or object, which we call Phenomenon, and is able to make predictions about the behavior or  occurrence of the Phenomenon.
frameExamples: Your boss is <t>aware</t> of your commitment.
You 've already <t>stereotyped</t> me as a bimbo, have n't you?
Lermontov was <t>certain</t> he would come to the party.
The single remaining piece of evidence <t>linked</t> Kirov the tailor to Kirov the dissident activist.
I figured this out last week and now I really <t>understand</t> it.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose awareness of phenomena is at question. With a target verb or adjective the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is generally expressed as an External Argument with the <fen>Content</fen> expressed as an Object or Complement.
The <fen>Content</fen> is the object of the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s awareness. <fen>Content</fen> can be expressed as a direct object or in a PP Complement.
Some verbs in this frame allow a <fen>Topic</fen> to be expressed in about-PPs.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part that reveals the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s state to the observer.
The time interval during which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is aware of the <fen>Content</fen>.
This is the person who performs an act of categorization. Typically, this frame element is expressed as an External Argument.
This is the entity which is construed or treated by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> as being an instance of a particular <fen>Category</fen>. Typically, the <fen>Item</fen> is expressed as an Object.

This frame element expresses a general type or class of which the <fen>Item</fen> is considered an instance. Typically, it is expressed in a prepositional phrase headed by <ment>as</ment> or <ment>under</ment>.

This frame element expresses properties of the <fen>Item</fen> which is used as a basis for categorization. <fen>Criteria</fen> are the general dimensions along which <fen>Item</fen>s can potentially differ from one another and hence, fall into different <fen>Category</fen>s. For example, a paint sample can be classified <ment>by color</ment> or <ment>by finish (matte or gloss)</ment>; if they are classified by color, one can be classified <ment>as orange</ment> and another <ment>as red</ment>. The <fen>Criteria</fen> role is typically expressed as a PP headed by <ment>by</ment>, or as a complex PP of the form <ment>on the basis of...</ment>:
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate when a certain Categorization was made.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose certainty or uncertainty is at issue.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the entity that a <fen>Cognizer</fen> has a certain/uncertain belief about.
The <fen>Content</fen> denotes the mental content that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is certain or uncertain about.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the mental state of  the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.

This is the person who believes some Phenomenon will take place in the future. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Cognizer'>Pat</fex> <t>expects</t> that the Yankees will win the World Series.

This is what the Cognizer believes will happen in the future. It can be expressed as a Finite Clause Complement, an NP Object, or a VP Complement with or without an NP Object (see General Grammatical Observations):
An entity that serves as the focus of a predicted <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the prediction.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> foresees the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The concept which is linked to <fen>Concept_2</fen>.
The concept which is tied to <fen>Concept_1</fen>.
The phenomenon that points to or proves the connection between <fen>Concept_1</fen> and <fen>Concept_2</fen>. Generally expressed as an external.
The two concepts expressed jointly.
The sentient animate being who acquires new knowledge.
A state of affairs or dynamic system whose internal make-up and working the Cognizer comes to assimilate into their knowledge structure.
A part  of a person's cognitive-emotional faculties that is said to acquire knowledge.
This role indicates the when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> asssimilates the new knowledge.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Your boss</fex> is aware of your commitment.
Your boss is aware <fex>of your commitment</fex>.
Kim knows <fex>about first aid</fex>.
Bob's <fex>eyes</fex> were overly aware

Yet there is no evidence that Mr. Parrish was cognizant <fex>at the time of the signing
of the notes</fex> that the clauses in issue were present.
<fex>Kim</fex> categorized the books under fiction. <fex>Kim</fex> categorized them on the basis of genre.
Kim categorized <fex>the books</fex> under fiction.
Kim categorized the book <fex>as/under fiction</fex>.
The students were categorized <fex>on the basis of their test scores</fex>.
<fex>20 years ago</fex> people would consider this as nothing unusual
<fex>Marcel</fex> was sure that she had seen Eldridge on the balcony.
She talked of quests , of finding this absurd religious character , but he was unsure <fex>of her conviction</fex>.
I am sure <fex>that we'll arrive on time</fex>.
She caught sight of her mother's dubious <fex>expression</fex>.
Pat expects <fex>that the Yankees will win the World Series</fex>.
Predictions <fex>about stock prices</fex> are notoriously undependable.
She predicted the outcry <fex>several months ago</fex>.
<fex>Even at the far side of the house</fex> I could predict what was going on the kitchen.
High death rates among smokers connect <fex>cigarettes</fex> with disease.
Skid marks on the street connects my neighbor's car <fex>to my broken mailbox</fex>.
<fex>Footprints</fex> connect her to the crime.
Ample evidence is able to connect <fex>the two</fex>.
<fex>Sue</fex> grasped the essentials right away
You must grasp <fex>the complex relationship of all these subjects to each other</fex>
<fex>My heart</fex> grasped that reality immediately.
<fex>Yesterday</fex> the students finally grasped the meaning of the equation

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
